title: Paul’s Ministry and Separation
shortSummary: In 2 Corinthians 6, Paul appeals to the Corinthian believers to not receive God's grace in vain and highlights the hardships endured in his ministry as a demonstration of genuine service. He exhorts believers to live holy lives by avoiding unequal partnerships with unbelievers, emphasizing their identity as the temple of the living God and calling them to separation from worldly influences.
timeline: c. AD 55-57 - Paul's Second Missionary Journey, during his ministry to the Corinthian church

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle and author of this letter, who defends his ministry and exhorts the Corinthians to faithful living.

keyCharacters.name: Corinthian Believers
keyCharacters.description: The recipients of Paul's letter, a church struggling with spiritual challenges and external influences.

definitions.definition: The unmerited favor and power of God given to believers for salvation and sanctification.
A metaphor from farming describing believers forming binding partnerships with unbelievers, which is discouraged due to conflicting values.
A biblical image describing believers collectively as God's dwelling place through the Holy Spirit.
A term used to represent wickedness or Satan, symbolizing evil and opposition to Christ.

outline.heading: Paul’s Appeal to Receive God’s Grace
outline.description: Paul urges the Corinthians to accept God’s grace sincerely and not waste the opportunity of salvation, referencing Isaiah to emphasize the urgency of the present time.

outline.heading: Paul’s Sufferings and Ministry Credentials
outline.description: Paul describes the many trials and virtues that characterize his ministry, demonstrating endurance, purity, and faithfulness despite hardships, to validate his apostleship.

outline.heading: Paul’s Open Heart to the Corinthians
outline.description: Paul expresses his deep affection and openness toward the Corinthians, encouraging them to respond with equal generosity of heart.

outline.heading: Exhortation to Separation from Unbelievers
outline.description: Paul commands believers to avoid close associations with unbelievers to preserve holiness, reminding them that they are God’s temple and must live distinctively as His people.

application: Accept and cherish the grace of God daily, recognizing the present moment as the time of salvation.
Endure trials and hardships with patience and faithfulness as evidence of genuine Christian ministry and character.
Maintain holiness by avoiding close partnerships with unbelievers that could compromise your faith and witness.
Remember your identity as God’s temple and live in a way that honors Him, separating from worldly influences.

keyVerses.text: (For he saith, I have heard thee in a time accepted, and in the day of salvation have I succoured thee: behold, now is the accepted time; behold, now is the day of salvation.)
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the urgency and privilege of responding to God's offer of salvation now.

keyVerses.text: Be ye not unequally yoked together with unbelievers: for what fellowship hath righteousness with unrighteousness? and what communion hath light with darkness?
keyVerses.significance: It teaches the vital principle of spiritual separation to protect the believer’s walk with God.

keyVerses.text: And what agreement hath the temple of God with idols? for ye are the temple of the living God; as God hath said, I will dwell in them, and walk in them; and I will be their God, and they shall be my people.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms the believer’s identity as God’s dwelling place, underscoring the call to holiness.
